metadata.name: Intangible #87
metadata.description:
Let me take you places. Those are not in your town, not even on your planet. They‚Äôre placed somewhere between reality and subconsciousness.
Enormous, peculiar structures emerge upon you, refusing to be ignored. They are your unfulfilled cravings or ever-lurking demons. They were always there, under your skin, intangible, now they‚Äôve materialized.
You may not like them, they may seem too vast, too scary to tame. But ultimately, you have to face them, unless you enjoy living in their shadow.¬†

___
Inspirations

I‚Äôve never truly realized that, but ever since I remember, the sight of gigantic objects or creatures evoked strong emotions within me.
It probably started with playing Shadow of Colossus (a video game) as a kid and seeing The Cathedral (short movie by Tomasz Bagi≈Ñski). Years later, reading Solaris (by Stanis≈Çaw Lem) aroused the same feeling (among others) of being mesmerized by the vastness. More recently, movies like Denis Villeneuve‚Äôs Arrival (which also nudged my attraction to mystery) and Dune - have charmed me.

Earlier this year I have stumbled across Dawid Planeta (artist and yoga teacher) and began contemplating his visions of mini people in the jungle inhabited by giant animals. These works in particular, plus Hollow - generative series by Jacek Markusiewicz - were probably my final inspirations to make Intangible look the way it does.

Settling semi-random generative structures in some kind of reality, gave them a meaning - they may symbolize things much bigger than you - the ones you try to escape from or those you‚Äôve been longing to experience for years. I have mine, don‚Äôt you?

___
Controls in live mode


Keyboard
[ space ] - toggle light animation
[ S ] - save image with current size (default is 120% of browser window‚Äôs height; you may change browser‚Äôs scale or check URL size param)
[ F ] - fullscreen¬†
[ up / down ] - light intensity
[ left / right ] - base light position
[ 1..5 ] - aspect ratio: 10:16 (‚Äûzero‚Äù ratio), 1:1.4142 (vertical A4), 1:1, 1.4142 (horizontal A4), 16:10
[ B ] - toggle border
[ Z ] - toggle canvas ‚Äûraw‚Äù mode - no shadow / margin (auto applied in fullscreen mode)
[ N ] - toggle ‚Äûthat thing you may not want on print‚Äù


URL params
You may add any number of parameters to the URL to start it with particular settings.‚Ä®
[ animate ] (1/0) - toggle light animation
[ size] (number) - number of px for longer edge, i.e. 4000
[ ratio ] (number or ratio with format: 10/16, 10:16, 10_16) - aspect ratio
[ light ] (number 40..120, some palettes have slightly different limits for good results) - light intensity
[ lightShift] (number -100..100) - base light position
[ border ] (1/0) - toggle border
[ hddcy ] (0/1)

Example: [ &size=4000&border=1&light=100&animate=1 ]¬†


Mobile
[hold 2 fingers for 2s] - save
[double tap] - fullscreen


___
Note:
I encourage you to do some light adjustments before you save an image for print. I‚Äôm pretty sure you can do better than fxrand().


___
Special thanks to my brother Krzycho, for lots of advices / heathy criticism and to Olga, for never-ending excitement and ‚Äûdorady‚Äù.

___
Developed in Javascript, using p5.js (2D Canvas) and chroma.js.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

¬© April-July 2022, MadeUpLifeforms (mulf)

metadata.name: Inertia #1245
metadata.description:
This project will be reserved and free for 48 hours, for all the holders of any of my projects!

The amount of reserves for each user will be equal to the amount of all the token held at 13:00 CEST [UTC+2] (May 23)
(example: user holds 3 "Figment" and 2 "ACCUMULATOR", will be able to mint "Inertia" 5 times)

48h from now I will update the reserves list and burn the remaining tokens

WARINING: The reserves will expire 48h after the drop! And a price for the unlocked mintables will be set (unreserved mints will not be free).

---

"Inertia is a property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force."

Particles are blasted from 2 to 4 sides of the canvas, each particle has its own mass and it has to traverse a friction-field, once it loses its momentum completely it stops and leaves a trace, adding or subtracting light from the canvas.

The friction-field has 18 possible mutation kinds.
Mutations are high-friction zones of various shapes.

Made just with JS on a canvas
right-click to save

metadata.name: Illusion City #54
metadata.description:
Illusion City reflects the variety of Istanbul by its different and divergent zones, day and night, humid summers and ice cold winters, colorful neighborhoods and giant plazas, its never ending human and vehicle traffic.

This series is an expression of how we experience this city, kind of like a love and hate relationship. The city that is a cradle of civilizations now has become a concrete jungle. Our beautiful city and its citizens are now trying to find their own balance in this state of chaos.

We wanted to express these complex emotions with a long-form generative artwork since it is the most suitable medium to explore every possible combination of emotions we have about our city. 

Best experienced in full screen.

Probabilities;

- 3 pre-made color palettes, 1 generative color palette

- 3 blend modes

- 3 topping placements

- 8 different particle angle compositions

- Several grid sizes and edges

- An intentionally kept in glitch (rare)

In live mode, press ‚Äòs‚Äô to save as .png (2000 x 2666 px )

It can take up to a minute to render or longer in low-performance computers. Enjoy the process!

Made with p5.js

Ilgƒ±n ƒ∞√ß√∂z√º, July 2022
@distcollective

metadata.name: Dragons #148
metadata.description:
A grid of many lines forming a dragon crafted on paper.
They all have their own personality... Be sure to name and take care of them.

tw: williamapan

metadata.name: Encircling #13
metadata.description:
Overlapping Vision.

There are no rarity attributes assigned to this artwork, its value is intended to be determined by viewer aesthetic alone.

This artwork was created using p5js and utilizes the p5.pattern library created by Taichi Sayama.

linktr.ee/lisaorthstudio
twitter: @lisaorthstudio

metadata.name: Distortion City Tool #224
metadata.description: This is the tool I created for Distortion City series. Click to draw the shape, toggle line and adjust the fxrand() (rnd and basement) to see how they distorted. Shift + click on the line to add points, shift + click on the point to delete the point. Save Json if you want to use in your program. This is not artwork but because all Distortion City Series stay at fxhash, I share here.

metadata.description: This is the tool I created for Distortion City series. Click to draw the shape, toggle line and adjust the fxrand() (rnd and basement) to see how they distorted. metadata.name: To make a botanist cry #277
metadata.description:
Totally accurate vine simulator.

There is nine different berries and a hidden item so use your mouse to find it.

metadata.name: Bored Computer Screen #598
metadata.description:
"Bored Computer Screen" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Art Basel, Basel 2022


Bored Computer Screen (BCS) is a direct descendant of Specterüëªpixel‚¨õlatte‚òï, where the central idea is agent and displacement. In BCS, there are agents‚Äîthe small moving circles‚Äîthat get their colors ripped away by the surrounding pixels. Though they occur on the same screen space, they are separated in their own cells, a simultaneous multiverse of sorts. In some iterations, a very clear voronoi pattern will appear. I didn't consciously strive for this look. It's what naturally happens, when you try to divide space, so that the borders occur exactly in between the closest neighbor. When I first saw this pattern emerge, I wanted to see how far I could get the distinct cells to influence each other. The idea that the same algorithmic processes can happen many times but still separately in a single piece has always interested me (and explored in the Infinite Browse series). BCS is an extension of that, albeit a little more chaotic.

Note:
- Best experience on browsers and devices with support for WebGL2 

Made by Sam Tsao (@sam___tsao) with P5, P5Fbo and perlinjs.

attributes.name: A More Descriptive Number of Cells

metadata.name: Techno Garden #4
metadata.description: The Techno Garden is full of magical flowers that like to listen to your stories. This collection adds more form factors and palettes. As always, the "gold" is rare and you can save with he 's' key.

metadata.name: Time Flow #2
metadata.description:
Showcase of world generation base on time. Everything are moving and show you how the world shaping. 

Move mouse on screen to increase time speed.

metadata.name: PolyGem #87
metadata.description:
PolyGem is inspired by my own experience when I was a child. I liked play with sands, rocks and many different beautiful stones. They had different layers with colorful textures and crystal structures. All of them caught my curiosity and my time after school.

In this project, I try to remember and describe my experience about beautiful stones and gems with abstract arts. Four types of layouts are designed and each with a recursive algorithm to construct the crystal structures. Five textures are picked to mimic the complex patterns inside of crystal cells. All above them are combining in a random way, but are balanced with local structures.

Variables:
- 4 layouts
- 5 textures
- 20 color sets

Please be patient with drawing process.

metadata.name: fxhash x thi.ng project template #163
metadata.description:
THIS IS NOT AN ARTWORK (at least not intentional)!

This NFT acts as a donation/funding mechanism for a new project template Git repo, providing a compact, ready-to-go scaffolding for generative art projects aimed at the fx(hash) platform/marketplace.

https://github.com/thi-ng/fxhash-tpl

This template evolved over time and has served as basis for some of the author's own NFT projects (https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/toxi). The template is aimed at TypeScript (but can be easily adapted to plain JavaScript) and, at the time of writing, uses Vite as dev & build tool, ensuring an altogether great & speedy workflow with minimal fuzz.

(In the future, I'm aiming to provide an alternative version for more advanced hybrid projects using TypeScript, Zig (https://ziglang.org) and WebAssembly (https://webassembly.org/)...)

Framework agnostic

Even though several packages from the https://thi.ng/umbrella ecosystem are used to provide various essential overarching functionality, the template is organized in such a way that the main parts are completely framework-agnostic. You should be able to easily plug in your own toolkit of choice, however I cannot promise to provide support for this myself (though happy to accept PRs, also in terms of further docs, how-tos, guides etc.)

Example project

A tiny, fully documented throwaway example sketch is included, illustrating the following:

- Overall project structure & build commands
- FXhash related setup
- Static & dynamic configuration and state (re)initialization (via dependency graph)
- FXhash PRNG wrapper & utilities
- Canvas & SVG conversion/export/download
- 2D geometry creation, transformation & drawing
- Basic vector algebra example usage


Keyboard shortcuts

- space :  pause/play animation
- x : download canvas as PNG
- s : download SVG version

In case of doubt, it's this example project what is used here for minting. The funding, however, will be used for the further maintenance of both this project template and supporting my other open source work. 20% are also donated to the FXhash development team itself.

Thank you for your support! üôèüòç
